title.narrative: Operationalizing UNIDO#s strategic support to small island developing States in line with the SAMOA Pathway

description.narrative:
The SIDS Accelerated Modalities of Action Pathway (SAMOA Pathway) was adopted at the ‘Third International Conference on SIDS’ held in Apia, Samoa, in September 2014. Among other UN agencies, UNIDO committed to its effective implementation, particularly in 10 priority areas related to its ISID mandate. 34 of the 38 SIDS that are members of the UN, are also Member States of UNIDO and have clear expectations on the Organization for support in these areas.
In 2016, a comprehensive review of UN System support for SIDS was carried out by the Joint Inspection Unit (JIU/REP/2016/7). It provided a number of recommendations, which UN agencies, including UNIDO, were asked to reflect in their future SIDS work. The recommendations included, among others, mainstreaming the SAMOA Pathway in strategic plans. In response to the JIU recommendations and to further support its SIDS Member States, UNIDO formulated a SIDS Strategy to support the implementation of the SAMOA Pathway.
The 18th session of UNIDO’s General Conference in Abu Dhabi adopted a resolution on the SIDS strategy which requests the Director General of UNIDO to implement the SIDS Strategy and to continue to align UNIDO’s SIDS programmes and projects to support the implementation of the SAMOA Pathway.
The purpose of this project is to support the operationalization of UNIDO’s SIDS strategy and the roadmap contained in it, with the aim of scaling up and integrating UNIDO interventions in SIDS. Once operationalized, the Strategy will also contribute to the implementation of the SAMOA Pathway and the Political Declaration adopted during the high-level mid-term review in October 2019. In particular, the project will aim to facilitate regional partnerships, multi-disciplinary interventions, enhanced resource flows, and innovative approaches to SIDS coverage in the context of the UN’s move towards multi-country offices (MCOs). It will also support regular reporting on progress to UNIDO’s governing bodies and the wider UN system.
